Egypt stands with respect to the law. Almost all the criticisms that we seen have been based upon the assumption that the government stands in the same relation to the law and the courts of justice as if it were nothing more than a private individual. It does not appear to have struck those who have been strongly protesting against Ford Cromer's action that a Government is, and must be, the paramount and dominant power in any and every country in which law and order are to prevail, and that if you render the Government subordinate to any other power it ceases in effect to be the government and, so far as it acts, or can act, becomes simply the executive or agent of the power that controls it. If, then, the law courts of Egypt are superior to the Government, it follows absolutely and inevitably that the law-courts constitute the real Government of the country. But if this be soif the law-courts are, separately or collectively, superior to the government, then they are superior to the laws, for the laws have no other force or validity than that which they derive from the government and obviously, if the law-courts can or may over-rule the government they may over-rule the laws, and they thus obtain despotic power, and the liberty, rights, and lives of the public are placed at their mercy.

It seems to us, therefore, that this is a matter in which the public must simply accept the action of the government, and should the government refuse to make known the reasons that induce it to exert its authority, it is the plain duty of all loyal subjects to accept that decision. No one familiar with the history of the last few years in Egypt can for a moment venture to dispute the assertion that the government has shown itself anxious in every way to promote the happiness and welfare of the people and the interests of the country, and it has shown its independent spirit more than once. If therefore the public refuse to accept the action of the government, it follows as a matter of course that they distrust it; and when we consider the composition of the government and the fact that it unquestionably represents the very best administrative material in the country, and numbers amongst its members some of the most enlightened and advanced men of the people, to declare it unworthy of the confidence of the public would, in effect, be to declare the country incapable of furnishing an efficient or reliable government. For the same reason, and the same way, the suggestion that he government has been constrained or unduly influenced in its decision can only tend to establish the same conclusion.

We think it well to call attention to what, as we have already said, appears to us to be an important aspect of the case that has been overlooked. We do know that some statements of fact or opinion that have been made are not based upon accurate knowledge, but our object in writing has been simply to indicate a view that has not been considered, and therefore we refrain from the discussion of what are in fact mere details, not having an important or conclusive influence upon the essential question involved in the affair, namely, whom are we to look to as the final and ultimately responsible governing body in this countrythe government or the law-courts. This is the point really at issue, and it is one that is of no slight significance, for, as we have shown, it involves consequences of the utmost importance. Either the law or the government must be supreme. If the view taken by some of our contemporaries be correct, then the law is the supreme power in this country, but as the consequences that would flow from this are such as we indicated, it would result that the public could have no other guarantee of their rights or privileges than the goodwill of the law, that is to say, of those in whose hands the administration of the law lies; and we scarcely think that any sane person will be prepared to advocate the application of such a principle to the administration of this or any other country.

div.head:
A TRAVELLED ARTIST.
ON HIS WAY TO THEBES.
div.p: Onoofthe most interesting latter-day artists who have made Bgypt their happy hunting- ground during recent years is Mr. Walter Tyndalp, who is now BDonding a few days in C*iro preparatory to finding his way to his old baont* at Thebes. Born in Brnge*, and passing all his youth amid the ieftnences of such plaoes as Bruges, Ghent, and Antwerp, it is doubtless that almost nooonrciously'be developed daring these early years (hat know- lodge and sympathy of architectural detail which charaoteriz* hi* work. From his boyhood he was a constant attendant at die art classes in Bruges ; and when only eighteen he became a regular student in Antwerp and afterwards ip Pari*, where he studied not only under Bonnet, bat alto in the stndio of that famous Belgian artist Jan van Beers. Curiously enough, Mr. Tyndtle's earlier work was ooi fined entirely to oils, and though his portraits brought him a certain notoriety they n ho way bo compared with the delicaoy of the water-oolour sketches for which be is now renowned.

Tho story of the disooVery of his own speoial gift is amnaingly told in ths "StoW of last September. It appears that like many another artist Bffr. Tyndale was in the habit of filling his spare boars io< giving lessons in painting, and be was not ariittle nonplussed on one occasion when t new lady pppil mado it o'ear to him that it was in water-oolonrs and notoils that she needed instruction. Unwilling to confess his ignorance of the sobject, Mr. Tyndale started to work with a shilling box of ooloors and brashes which hsd already been of service in the gom bottle. The sketch that was prodneed under these conditions is most likely now a cherished possession.of that lady pupil, and though Mr. Tyndale speak* of it as being "too frightful for anything," still his recent successes maybe said to have sprang from this strange chanoe, and never from that day has he deserted his favourite meliom.

An unwearied traveller and nne thoroughly at homo in all land», Mr. Tyndale ha* songht and found inspiration in most European oountrie* and in many farther afield. Morocco, Bgypt, Lebanon, D*masons, 8ici!y, Portugal, Bavuia, and many other plaoes bave given him suhjeots for his untiring penoil ; and his oolonr illustrations to "The New Forest," and to Thomas Hardy's "Wes*ex" are worthy of the highest praise. His lova of architecture and appreciation of its.valoe were doubtless due to his early sorrouodings ; the delioacy of his work and detail may partly due to his master, Jan van Bear*. His facility of composition is intuitive, and the pority cf hi* colouring is often exquisite in it* rendering.

Mr. Tyndale has already had varions exhibitions of his works, and bis commissions keep him bnsy all the year through. Ths work of this present winter it to be shown at the Leicester Galleries.next June, and already his movements and travels ara plaonsd for many

>nths ahead. It is mnob to bo regretted that none of hie work is to be on view in this conntry, but those who love thi* land of Egypt will look forward to refreshing their memories at his exhibition ol eastern sketches
London.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.
